![](images/download.jpg){width="600"}



# vector

A vector is an ordered collection of basic data types of a given length. The only key thing here is all the elements of a vector must be same data type e.g homogeneous data structures. Vectors are one-dimensional data structures.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
a = c(1, 2, 3, 4)
a
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3 4
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(a)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "numeric"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
b =  c("Debi", "Sandeep", "Subham", "Shiba")
b
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Debi"    "Sandeep" "Subham"  "Shiba"  
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "character"
```


:::
:::

## create vector


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
seq(from = 2, to = 14, by = 2) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1]  2  4  6  8 10 12 14
```


:::
:::


other way:

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rep(x = 1.5, times = 4)  
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1.5 1.5 1.5 1.5
```


:::
:::





## append vector


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x=c(1,2,3)
y=c(4,5,6)
z=c(x,y)
z
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5 6
```


:::
:::


## calculate vector


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x=c(1,2,3,4,5)

sum(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 15
```


:::
:::



## select vector element

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x=c(1,2,3)

x[1]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1
```


:::
:::


## vector  Converting between types


### to factor

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c("a", "g", "b")
y=as.factor(x)
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] a g b
Levels: a b g
```


:::
:::




### to numeric

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c('123','44', '222')
y=as.numeric(x)
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 123  44 222
```


:::
:::



### to character

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(123123,111,5555)
y=as.character(x)
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "123123" "111"    "5555"  
```


:::
:::


### to boolen

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(1,0,1)
y=as.logical(x)
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE
```


:::
:::




## vector to other data format


### vector to dataframe


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Name <- c("Jhon", "Lee", "Suzan", "Abhinav", 
          "Brain", "Emma", "David", "Alice") 

   
Marks <- c(56, 76, 86, 96, 73, 87, 47, 98) 
    

data<- data.frame(Name,Marks) 
data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     Name Marks
1    Jhon    56
2     Lee    76
3   Suzan    86
4 Abhinav    96
5   Brain    73
6    Emma    87
7   David    47
8   Alice    98
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(data)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "data.frame"
```


:::
:::



### verctor to matrix


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
v1 <- c(56, 76, 86, 96, 73, 87, 47, 98) 
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data<-matrix(v1,nrow=4)
data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]   56   73
[2,]   76   87
[3,]   86   47
[4,]   96   98
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(data)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "matrix" "array" 
```


:::
:::


other way:

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data<-matrix(c(v1,v1),ncol = 2)
data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]   56   56
[2,]   76   76
[3,]   86   86
[4,]   96   96
[5,]   73   73
[6,]   87   87
[7,]   47   47
[8,]   98   98
```


:::
:::



### verctor to list


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data=list(v1)
data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
[1] 56 76 86 96 73 87 47 98
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(data)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "list"
```


:::
:::



each element in vetor as a element in list



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
data=as.list(v1)
data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
[1] 56

[[2]]
[1] 76

[[3]]
[1] 86

[[4]]
[1] 96

[[5]]
[1] 73

[[6]]
[1] 87

[[7]]
[1] 47

[[8]]
[1] 98
```


:::
:::

### verctor to array

3D array

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
vec1=c(1:5) 
 
vec2=c(6:10) 
 
arr=array(c(vec1,vec2),dim=c(2,5,3)) 
 
# printing the array
class(arr)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "array"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
arr
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
, , 1

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5]
[1,]    1    3    5    7    9
[2,]    2    4    6    8   10

, , 2

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5]
[1,]    1    3    5    7    9
[2,]    2    4    6    8   10

, , 3

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5]
[1,]    1    3    5    7    9
[2,]    2    4    6    8   10
```


:::
:::


# Dataframe

Dataframes are generic data objects of R which are used to store the tabular data. Dataframes are the foremost popular data objects in R programming because we are comfortable in seeing the data within the tabular form. They are two-dimensional, heterogeneous data structures


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# A vector which is a character vector
Name = c("Amiya", "Raj", "Asish")

# A vector which is a character vector
Language = c("R", "Python", "Java")

# A vector which is a numeric vector
Age = c(22, 25, 45)

# To create dataframe use data.frame command
# and then pass each of the vectors 
# we have created as arguments
# to the function data.frame()
df = data.frame(Name, Language, Age)

df
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
   Name Language Age
1 Amiya        R  22
2   Raj   Python  25
3 Asish     Java  45
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(df)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "data.frame"
```


:::
:::



## dataframe to other data format


### dataframe to matrix


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mat <- as.matrix(df)

class(mat)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "matrix" "array" 
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mat
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     Name    Language Age 
[1,] "Amiya" "R"      "22"
[2,] "Raj"   "Python" "25"
[3,] "Asish" "Java"   "45"
```


:::
:::


### dataframe to vector


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
vec=df[['Name']]

class(vec)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "character"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
vec
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Amiya" "Raj"   "Asish"
```


:::
:::


### dataframe to list


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
list=as.list(df[['Name']])

class(list)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "list"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
list
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
[1] "Amiya"

[[2]]
[1] "Raj"

[[3]]
[1] "Asish"
```


:::
:::


# Matrices

A matrix is a rectangular arrangement of numbers in rows and columns. In a matrix, as we know rows are the ones that run horizontally and columns are the ones that run vertically. Matrices are two-dimensional, homogeneous data structures.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
A = matrix(
    # Taking sequence of elements
    c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9), 
    
    # No of rows and columns
    nrow = 3, ncol = 3,  

    # By default matrices are 
    # in column-wise order 
    # So this parameter decides
    # how to arrange the matrix          
    byrow = TRUE                             
)

A
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    2    3
[2,]    4    5    6
[3,]    7    8    9
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(A)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "matrix" "array" 
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
matrix002=A+A

matrix002
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    2    4    6
[2,]    8   10   12
[3,]   14   16   18
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
matrix003=A*A

matrix003
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    4    9
[2,]   16   25   36
[3,]   49   64   81
```


:::
:::


## matrix to other data format


### matrix to dataframe



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df <- as.data.frame(matrix003)

class(df)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "data.frame"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
  V1 V2 V3
1  1  4  9
2 16 25 36
3 49 64 81
```


:::
:::


### matrix to vector


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
vec=as.vector(matrix003)

class(vec)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "numeric"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
vec
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1]  1 16 49  4 25 64  9 36 81
```


:::
:::



### matrix to list


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
list=as.list(matrix003)

class(list)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "list"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
list
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
[1] 1

[[2]]
[1] 16

[[3]]
[1] 49

[[4]]
[1] 4

[[5]]
[1] 25

[[6]]
[1] 64

[[7]]
[1] 9

[[8]]
[1] 36

[[9]]
[1] 81
```


:::
:::


# Lists

A list is a generic object consisting of an ordered collection of objects. Lists are heterogeneous data structures. These are also one-dimensional data structures. A list can be a list of vectors, list of matrices, a list of characters and a list of functions and so on.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
empId = c(1, 2, 3, 4)

# The second attribute is the employee name 
# which is created using this line of code here
# which is the character vector 
empName = c("Debi", "Sandeep", "Subham", "Shiba")

# The third attribute is the number of employees
# which is a single numeric variable.
numberOfEmp = 4

# We can combine all these three different
# data types into a list
# containing the details of employees
# which can be done using a list command
empList = list(empId, empName, numberOfEmp)

empList
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3 4

[[2]]
[1] "Debi"    "Sandeep" "Subham"  "Shiba"  

[[3]]
[1] 4
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(empList)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "list"
```


:::
:::


# Arrays

3D arrays


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
A = array(
    # Taking sequence of elements
    c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8),

    # Creating two rectangular matrices 
    # each with two rows and two columns
    dim = c(2, 2, 2)                        
)

A
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
, , 1

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    3
[2,]    2    4

, , 2

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    5    7
[2,]    6    8
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
class(A)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "array"
```


:::
:::



# Reference:

https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/data-structures-in-r-programming/
